Please note that a path of length k means visiting exactly k cells (not necessarily distinct). You CANNOT go off the grid. A path A (of length k) is considered less than a path B (of length k) if after making the ordered vectors of the values on the cells that A and B go through (let's call them lst_A and lst_B), lst_A is lexicographically less than lst_B, in other words, there exist an integer index i (1 <= i <= k) such that lst_A[i] < lst_B[i] and for any j (1 <= j < i) we have lst_A[j] = lst_B[j]. <|endoftext|>/*
Return vector of all prefixes from shortest to longest of the input string
>>> all_prefix("abc")
{"a", "ab", "abc"}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
vector<string> all_prefix(string str){
    vector<string> prefixes(str.size());
    for(int i=0;i<str.size();i++){
        prefixes[i] = str.substr(0,i);
    }
    return prefixes;
}
/*
Return vector of all suffixes from shortest to longest of the input string
>>> all_suffix("abc")
{"a", "ab", "abc", "ba", "bca", "cab", "cba", "caba", "cbaa"}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
vector<string> all_suffix(string str){
    vector<string> suffixes(str.size());
    for(int i=0;i<str.size();i++){
        suffixes[i] = str.substr(i+1);
    }
    return suffixes;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Write a function which sorts the given vector of integers
in ascending order according to the sum of their digits.
Note: if there are several items with similar sum of their digits,
order them based on their index in original vector.

For example:
>>> holy_order_by_point({1, 11, -1, -11, -12}) == {-1, -11, 1, -12, 11}
>>> holy_order_by_point({}) == {}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
vector<int> holy_order_by_point(vector<int> nums){
    vector<int> ans;
    int sum = 0;
    for(int i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++){
        sum += nums[i];
        ans.push_back(sum);
    }
    sort(ans.begin(), ans.end());
    return ans;
}

Given a positive integer, obtain its roman numeral equivalent as a string,
and return it in lowercase.
Restrictions: 1 <= num <= 1000

Examples:
>>> int_to_mini_roman(19) == "xix"
>>> int_to_mini_roman(152) == "clii"
>>> int_to_mini_roman(426) == "cdxxvi"
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<vector>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
string int_to_mini_romank(int number){
    string result;
    vector<string> nums;
    nums.push_back(to_string(number));
    while(nums.back().length() > 1){
        nums.pop_back();
    }
    for(int i = 0; i < nums.size(); i++){
        string num = nums[i];
        for(int j = num.length() - 1; j >= 0; j--){
            num = num[j] + num[j + 1];
        }
        num = num.substr(0, num.length() - 1);
        result += num;
    }
    return result;
}

<|endoftext|>/*
Return only positive numbers in the vector.
>>> catch_positive({-1, 2, -4, 5, 6})
{2, 5, 6}
>>> catch_positive({5, 3, -5, 2, -3, 3, 9, 0, 123, 1, -10})
{5, 3, 2, 3, 9, 123, 1}
*/
#include<stdio.h>
#include<math.h>
#include<vector>
using namespace std;
vector<float> catch_positive(vector<float> l){
    vector<float> result;
    for(int i=0;i<l.size();i++){
        if(l[i]>0){
            result.push_back(l[i]);
        }
    }
    return result;
}

double poly(vector<double> xs, double x){
    /* 
    Evaluates polynomial with coefficients xs at point x. return xs[0] + xs[1] * x + xs[1] * x^2 +.... xs[n] * x^n 
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*pow(x,i);
    }
    return sum;
}

double find_zero(vector<double> xs){
    /*
    xs are coefficients of a polynomial. find_zero find x such that poly(x) = 0. find_zero returns only only zero point, even if there are many. 
    Moreover, find_zero only takes list xs having even number of coefficients and largest non zero coefficient as it guarantees a solution.
    >>> round(find_zero([1, 2]), 2) #f(x) = 1 + 2x 
    -0.5 
    >>> round(find_zero([-6, 11, -6, 1]), 2) # (x - 1) * (x - 2) * (x - 3) = -6 + 11x - 6x^2 + x^3 
    1.0
    */
    double sum=0;
    int i;
    double sum2=0;
    for (i=0;i<xs.size();i++)
    {
        sum+=xs[i]*xs[i];
        sum2+=xs[i]*xs[i];
    }
    double zero=sum/sum2;
    return zero;
}

true

#include<stdio.h>
#include<string>
using namespace std;
bool right_bracketing(string brackets){
    string opening_brackets = brackets;
    string closing_brackets = brackets;
    for(int i = 0; i < opening_brackets.length(); i++){
        if(opening_brackets[i] == '('){
            opening_brackets = opening_brackets.substr(0, i) + closing_brackets.substr(i+1);
            closing_brackets = closing_brackets.substr(0, i) + opening_brackets.substr(i+1);
        }
    }
    return opening_brackets == closing_brackets;
}

Create a function that takes a value (string) representing a number
and returns the closest integer to it. If the number is equidistant
from two integers, round it away from zero.

Examples
>>> close_integer("10")
10
>>> close_integer("15.3")
15

Note:
Rounding away from zero means that if the given number is equidistant
from two integers, the one you should return is the one that is the
farthest from zero. For example close_integer("14.5") should
return 15 and close_integer("-14.5") should return -15.
*/
